clinical_study.brief_title: Altered MAstication Contribute to TMJ PAin
clinical_study.official_title: One Habitual Chewing Side May Contribute to Chronic Temporomandibular Joint Disorder Pain

brief_summary.textblock:
The cause of temporomandibular joint disorders remains unknown. It is considered multifactorial and includes physical (peripheral) and psychosocial (central) factors. It has been showed an association: a steeper condylar path, flatter lateral anterior guidance, and habitual chewing on the symptomatic side. This finding argues the possibility of causation of some of these characteristics. This double blind longitudinal study aims to assess if the presence of one habitual chewing side could contribute to temporomandibular joint disorders over time.
Method. Young adults with no signs or symptoms of TMD will be assessed. Participants with one chewing side (observed and interview); with steeper condylar path and lower lateral guidance angles will be considered consistent one side chewers, and this side will be considered more susceptible to suffer TMD. Mouth opening, hemispheric dominance and hemimandibular retrognathia will be considered as secondary pre-specified outcomes. Four years later, both TMJs of each participant presenting signs and/or symptoms will be evaluated according to DC/TMD.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence or not of symptoms of temporomandibular joint disorders according to DC/TMD
Change of maximal unassited jaw opening
primary_outcome.description: Maximum unassisted jaw opening or interincisal distance (from edge to edge) measured by a Boley gauge. Up 38 in females and up 40 mm in males are considered limited.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of condylar paths angles inclination
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 3-4-years follow-up (end of the study)
secondary_outcome.description: Alteration of parasagittal plane Axiography of condyle motion in respect Frankfort horizontal plane

secondary_outcome.measure: Alteration of lateral dental guidance angles
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 4-years follow-up (end of the study)
secondary_outcome.description: Angle between Frankfort plane and lateral dental anterior guidance

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of maximal comfortable jaw opening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 4-years follow-up (end of the study)
secondary_outcome.description: Maximum jaw opening or interincisal distance (from edge to edge) measured by a Boley gauge. Up 38 in females and up 40 mm in males are considered limited.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of the habitual chewing side
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 3-4-years follow-up (end of the study)
secondary_outcome.description: Determining the habitual chewing side by direct observation using chewing gum, First cicle, and subsequent cicles (7 or over of 10 cicles), interview (used one habitual chewing side?: 1, no, alternate; 2, yes, right; 3, yes, left; 4, I don't know) and kinesiography.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of lateral deviation during maximal unassisted jaw opening

other_outcome.description: Interincisal median midline and Angle Class on each side

other_outcome.measure: Hemispheric dominance, asuming oposite side to handedness preference

intervention.description: OBSERVATIONAL, DIAGNOSTIC PROCEDURES. Young adults with no signs or symptoms of TMD will be assessed. The chewing function, condylar path angles and lateral guidance angles will be recorded. Maximum comfortable and unassisted jaw opening, hemispheric dominance and hemimandibular retrognathia will be considered as secondary pre-specified outcomes. Three-Four years later, both TMJs of each participant presenting signs and/or symptoms will be evaluated according to DC/TMD. Same recordings as baseline will be carried out.

study_pop.textblock: Medical or Dental School students. Healthy young adults with fully dentate normal occlusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthies
- full dentates
- normal occlusion
- One habitual chewing side
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe malocclusion, dental decay, severe periodontal disease.
Pains from other origins or Orthodontics are not criteria for exclusion
